sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the following reaction at 25°C given the enthalpies of formation (in kJ/mol) of the compounds involved:

CaCO3(s) + 2HCl(aq) → CaCl2(aq) + CO2(g) + H2O(l)

Hf(CaCO3) = -1206.9 kJ/mol
Hf(CaCl2) = -795.8 kJ/mol
Hf(CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
Hf(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol
Hf(HCl) = -92.31 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH° = Σ [Hf(products)] - Σ [Hf(reactants)]

For the products:
Hf(CaCl2) = -795.8 kJ/mol
Hf(CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
Hf(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

For the reactants:
Hf(CaCO3) = -1206.9 kJ/mol
Hf(HCl) = -92.31 kJ/mol (there are 2 moles of HCl, so multiply by 2)

Now, plug the values into the formula:

ΔH° = [(-795.8) + (-393.5) + (-285.8)] - [(-1206.9) + 2 × (-92.31)]

ΔH° = (-1475.1) - (-1391.52)

ΔH° = 83.58 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is 83.58 kJ/mol.
